title: Experiential Learning Design for Online Laboratory-Based Mathematics STEM Education

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of basic mathematical concepts (functions, calculus, statistics) and intermediate-level application skills (solving equations, interpreting graphs, experimental design)
context.additional_context: Pre-service teachers acquire methods to design and operate STEM experiments (calculus/statistics-based physics/engineering experiments) linked to mathematics curricula.

learning_goals: Perform virtual equipment operation and experimental data analysis (formula derivation, graph interpretation, error calculation) on an online lab platform with over 80% accuracy.

Learners will apply Kolb’s experiential learning theory (four stages: concrete experience → reflective observation → abstract conceptualization → active experimentation) to design at least one math experiment proposal (calculus/statistics-based) within a 2–4 week mid-term course, achieving over 4 points (out of 5) in peer evaluation rubrics (clarity, theory applicability, feasibility).
Provide at least three constructive feedbacks (e.g., formal derivation process, variable control methods) on peers’ experiment designs through peer evaluation.
Develop at least two online-offline integration strategies (e.g., virtual experiment-real measurement linkage, data visualization collaboration) to enhance learner engagement in blended environments.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
